Award.AwardTitle: FRG: Collaborative Research: Geometric Structures of Higher Teichmuller Spaces
Award.AbstractNarration:
A surface is a space which looks locally like the 2-dimensional plane, e.g. the surface of a basketball or a pretzel. Surfaces arise naturally in many scientific fields. A geometric structure is a way of measuring distances and angles on a surface or more complicated object. Studying spaces of geometric structures (or shapes) on a fixed object gives further information about their nature. The classical Teichmuller theory studies a space which parametrizes certain geometric structures (of constant curvature) on a fixed surface. Teichmuller theory has impacted diverse areas in mathematics, including algebraic geometry, complex analysis, low-dimensional topology, and dynamics, as well as theoretical physics through its connections with string theory. A metric on Teichmuller space is a way of measuring the distance, or difference, between two such geometric structures. The PIs plan to study metrics on a generalization of this theory called Higher Teichmuller Theory. Higher Teichmuller spaces may be viewed as deformation spaces of geometric structures on higher-dimensional spaces. It shares some of the nice properties of the classical theory and has become a very active field of research. The PIs will mentor graduate students who will be engaged in aspects of the project. They will also run a program which helps science and engineering students from low-resource high schools transition to college studies.

Higher Teichmuller theory studies spaces of "geometric" representations of a hyperbolic group into a semi-simple Lie group. The main goal is to develop a theory which shares the richness, beauty and versatility of classical Teichmuller theory. The Higher theory has exploded in popularity because of the interactions it fosters between the subjects of geometric topology, real and complex differential geometry, Lie theory, algebraic geometry, string theory, and dynamics. Bridgeman, Canary, Labourie and Sambarino used thermodynamic formalism to construct a pressure metric on many higher Teichmuller spaces which is motivated by Thurston's definition of the Weil-Petersson metric on Teichmuller space (and its reformulations by Bonahon and McMullen). In the special case of the Hitchin component, the pressure metric is a mapping class group invariant, analytic Riemannian metric whose restriction to the Fuchsian locus is a multiple of the Weil-Petersson metric. Wolf developed an analogous approach to the Weil-Petersson metric, and has results on the isometry group and curvature of the Weil-Petersson metric, degeneration of hyperbolic structures, and on harmonic maps (Hitchin equations) approaches to Teichmuller theory. Wentworth has worked on the pressure metric, Weil-Petersson geometry, Higgs bundles and harmonic maps. The PIs together propose to study the isometry group, curvature and metric completion of both the pressure metric and variants on Hitchin components and quasifuchsian spaces, aiming to understand the pressure metric on general higher Teichmuller spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Surfaces are ubiquitous in nature and in scientific and engineering inquiries.   They are membranes that separate substances and bubbles that float in the air.  They come in a variety of shapes and often those shapes reflect media in which the surfaces are found. Much of the intellectual work of this project is to mathematically describe the total collection of the geometries that surfaces may have.

To this goal, we add a new ingredient. The space that we live in is quite symmetric: if we had no landmarks or gravity to guide us, the world would look the same no matter which way we turned our head.  The surface of the earth has a separate, spherical symmetry: because the earth is round, we perceive a different symmetry.  It turns out that there is a vast abundance of distinct ambient spaces with quite different symmetries. This research is related to describing the collection of geometries that a surface may have and how they relate to the symmetries of the space in which they may live.  Moreover, we are often interested in shapes that are most efficient in some ways, in the sense that if they were made of some flexible material but required to contain some obstacles, they they would stretch in some ways characteristic of the required constraints and reflecting the symmetries of the space containing them.

We completed a number of projects that elaborated on these general themes.  Most of our work described images of surfaces that were required to have least energy among candidates that were all constrained similarly.  We then imagined the outcomes when the constraints were allowed to become extreme: in that case, dominant geometries on the highly energetic surfaces emerged that quite simply reflected the constraints. 

This sort of analysis had impacts across subfields in mathematics.  There are mathematicians that study the space of shapes of surfaces in topological ways, using sophisticated algebraic methods, and there are mathematicians that study the same space in analytic ways, using quite technical extensions of calculus in their investigations.  Much of our work aims to unite these perspectives, creating a weak dictionary between perspectives.  The value of this is that results that are expected from one point-of-view can be surprises in the other.

While engaged in the pursuit of these intellectual objectives, we involve and train young people who then enter the scientific workforce.  Two students supported by this grant obtained their Ph.D.'s and began their scientific careers. At the same time, a postdoc continued his development. In addition, this project partially supported a program to facilitate the transition of students of exceptional scientific potential from less-well-resourced high schools to undergraduate STEM majors at a research university.  These students are both particularly valuable members of the workforce -- since they often come from low-income backgrounds and/or are the first in their families to go to college and/or are members of groups which are under-represented in the technical workforce and they are talented -- and are at greater risk of attrition from technical majors because their preparation may not be at the same level as their peers.  Our comprehensive suite of interventions has succeeded in cutting the attrition from these groups roughly in half to the level that, in the large, they are retained in STEM majors at the same rate (about 75%) as their peers who might have come from better-resourced high schools. We have published papers on our approach and consulted with other schools who are interested in such programs.
